pageContext.title: A $10 billion streaming boom is coming to Asia. But are content creators ready?
pageContext.content:
As more and more people ditch TV, Asia is set for a massive switchover to watching content online in the next few years, as well as big investments in content that will create jobs.

While Netflix-style services spent US$2.7 billion on content for Asian audiences in 2017, that will rocket to US$10.1 billion by 2022, according to a report by consulting firm Alpha Beta out this week.

Photo credit: Pixnoo / 123RF

Around US$4 billion of this future spending is in the form of foreign direct investment into the region by global players, creating Asian content for the continent’s streamers as well as viewers around the world. That cash will create approximately 736,000 Asian jobs, says the report.

The world is watching

Streaming services “are increasingly enabling the dissemination of Asian content to wider audiences abroad,” says the study. “For example, the TV series Sacred Games from India and the film Okja out of South Korea were both watched online by viewers in over 190 countries, a reach unexpected with traditional distribution.”

A scene from Okja. Image credit: Netflix

“Asian audiences have a strong appetite for local content. Contrary to common belief, viewers in Asian countries spend equal time watching local and foreign content,” adds the report. That’s despite greater access to overseas content on the web.

While that preference varies quite a bit across markets, it’s more consistent across age groups:

Image credit: Alpha Beta

The true impact of that US$10.1 billion put into content will be three times larger than the sum spent, amounting to US$30.4 billion in economic benefits that ripple out toward supporting industries like catering, merchandise, and tourism.

Action!

Hooq and iFlix, two of Netflix’s biggest challengers in Asia, are already ramping up investment in original content ahead of the streaming boom.

What they’re fighting over is Asia’s 331.5 million streaming subscribers – up 35 percent from the previous year.

After starting to produce its own originals in 2017, iFlix in September announced it’ll quadruple its roster of self-produced shows by 2019, adding at least 12 original television series and 30 movies, plus putting more emphasis on sports and music.

“Local people want local stories,” says Jason Monteiro, global marketing director at iFlix.

“If you rewind to two-and-a-half years ago when we first started in Indonesia, we had a very heavy, western, Hollywood blockbuster lineup.” Although that was being watched, iFlix decided to “reprogram everything and actually focus on local content and focus a lot more on regional content,” Monteiro explained recently at Tech in Asia Jakarta 2018.

“We did our first original – Magic Hour, a TV series – in December last year. It’s eight-part […], about 45 minutes per episode. And it was a box set that was locally produced – local stories, local actors, local directors. And just one box set of Magic Hour did more minutes, more viewers, than all our Disney catalog combined,” he added.

The reason why? Monteiro feels it was because it was an “Indonesian, progressive, differentiated” show that is “much more relevant for local audiences.”

Netflix boss Reed Hastings. Photo credit: Tech in Asia.

Hooq last year debuted its first originals, promising there are plenty more in the pipeline.

According to Hooq’s Indonesia head Guntur Siboro, speaking on the same panel as Monteiro, the biggest challenge in ramping up so much regional content is that the supply of talent ready to make new movies or TV shows “is very scarce.”

“The content creators in Asia are not good enough,” Siboro added. “I blame the education system here – memorizing, memorizing. We are not creating stories. So I think that needs to be fixed.”

Siboro also sees that viewers need to be lured away from the kind of low-quality, cheesy, ad-filled free web series that have been sprouting up recently – the kind of shows that have, he pointed out, 50 episodes in a season.

Netflix has nabbed 11.8 percent of the streaming market across Asia, and will advance to 14.3 percent in 2020, predicts Emarketer.

Amazon Prime Video is another rival.

Netflix started on its Asian originals in 2016, having an early smash-hit with the Palme d’Or-nominated Okja, the tale of a young girl who takes on an evil multinational after it kidnaps her giant mutant pig.

Updated November 2, 9:48am: An earlier version of this article misspelled Jason Monteiro’s surname.
